messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] saya for kodzuka
messages.msgSnippet: Cleaning out the email box... Dean- Not sure if anyone answered this question. You might look into to Tosu, there should be some online sources and I believe
messages.messageBody:
Cleaning out the email box...

Dean-
Not sure if anyone answered this question. You might look into to
Tosu, there should be some online sources and I believe that while
these "utility knives" influenced the early development of the the
sword, they also never really went out of style and simply evolved
into the kogatana/kozuka we know from later periods...
MHO
-t

On Dec 19, 2005, at 6:17 AM, Dean Wayland wrote:

> H All,
>
> Were kodzuka ever supplied with a saya of their own? If so, what form
> did it take? Or, were these utility knives never carried
> independent of
> wakizashi/katana saya?
>
> Yours
>
> Dean
> ***
>
> Dean Wayland
>
>

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] saya for kodzuka
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Rich, ... Thanks again, your help is appreciated. I m trying to find out, how, if at all, these kogatana, were used/carried, during the 16th and early 17th
messages.messageBody:
Hi Rich,

>Hi Dean, just the basic Shirasaya that has been "rounded off" and gloss
>lacquered black. No same nor kodogu of any type. I will see if I can
>find anything. I have seen many online in auction in shirasaya, with and
>with out Sayagaki. I think these are just resting scabbards and a
>typical shirasaya is. They would have little application in mounting I
>think. This also could well be a modern phenomenon.
>
>best wishes
>
>Rich

Thanks again, your help is appreciated.

I'm trying to find out, how, if at all, these kogatana, were
used/carried, during the 16th and early 17th centuries, when not
associated with a daisho or the like. I'm thinking of buying one of Fred
Lohman's replica kogatana and then having it mounted in appropriate
fashion (once I know what that is).

If you come across anything useful, let me know, thanks again.

Yours

Dean
***
Dean Wayland

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] saya for kodzuka
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Dean, just the basic Shirasaya that has been rounded off and gloss lacquered black. No same nor kodogu of any type.  I will see if I can find anything. I
messages.messageBody:
Hi Dean, just the basic Shirasaya that has been "rounded off" and gloss
lacquered black. No same nor kodogu of any type. I will see if I can
find anything. I have seen many online in auction in shirasaya, with and
with out Sayagaki. I think these are just resting scabbards and a
typical shirasaya is. They would have little application in mounting I
think. This also could well be a modern phenomenon.

best wishes

Rich

>
>Anyway, when you say that you've seen ko-gatana in lacquered saya and
>tsuka, what form does the latter take, same-maki, ito-maki or something
>else? Also, I presume, the kodzuka mounting is only used when the ko-
>gatana is housed in the saya pocket of a wakizashi or katana, or does it
>crop up with lacquered saya?
>
>Much thanks
>
>Dean
>***
>Dean Wayland
>
>
>
>
>
>Yahoo! Groups Links
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>

--

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] saya for kodzuka
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Rich, ... Thanks for the reply, and yes I know that the kodzuka is actually the handle, it s just a very bad habit on my part, so carry on nit-picking,
messages.messageBody:
Hi Rich,

>Hi Dean, Ko-gatana ( the blades do come in Shirasaya and I have seen the
>odd one in a lacquered saya and tsuka. Kozuka are the handles actually.
>I know I am Nit-picking probably but there names seem to get more and
>more mixed up these days.
>
>cheers
>
>Rich

Thanks for the reply, and yes I know that the kodzuka is actually the
handle, it's just a very bad habit on my part, so carry on nit-picking,
please, so that (a) I'll learn something and (b) I'll stop being a
"nit":-)

Anyway, when you say that you've seen ko-gatana in lacquered saya and
tsuka, what form does the latter take, same-maki, ito-maki or something
else? Also, I presume, the kodzuka mounting is only used when the ko-
gatana is housed in the saya pocket of a wakizashi or katana, or does it
crop up with lacquered saya?

Much thanks

Dean
***
Dean Wayland

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: tosho tsuba question
messages.msgSnippet: Hi, sorry I use free image hosting try these: I bought these 2 tsubas as part of a box lot.  The first is very thin only .098 (2.48 mm) thick by 2.9 (73.66
messages.messageBody:
Hi,
sorry I use free image hosting try these:

I bought these 2 tsubas as part of a box lot. The first is very
thin only .098" (2.48 mm) thick by 2.9" (73.66 mm) round. I know it
isn't a good test but it rings like crystal and sounds unlike other
tsubas I have. The plate feels very good in the hand. The patina is
darker but the pictures in all were lightened to show texture. Any
ideas on the age and what the circle and box represent?

http://img393.imageshack.us/my.php?image=tosho14oh.jpg<http://img393.imageshack.us/my.php?image=tosho14oh.jpg>

http://img393.imageshack.us/my.php?image=tosho29hl.jpg<http://img393.imageshack.us/my.php?image=tosho29hl.jpg>

The second is a little thicker .125" (3.17mm ) thick by 3.0" (76.71
mm) round. Any idea on the age and what the double circles and thing
on the bottom represents?

http://img393.imageshack.us/my.php?image=tosho36ev.jpg<http://img393.imageshack.us/my.php?image=tosho36ev.jpg>

http://img393.imageshack.us/my.php?image=tosho49xx.jpg<http://img393.imageshack.us/my.php?image=tosho49xx.jpg>

thanks
dirk

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] saya for kodzuka
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Dean, Ko-gatana ( the blades do come in Shirasaya and I have seen the odd one in a lacquered saya and tsuka. Kozuka are the handles actually. I know I am
messages.messageBody:
Hi Dean, Ko-gatana ( the blades do come in Shirasaya and I have seen the
odd one in a lacquered saya and tsuka. Kozuka are the handles actually.
I know I am Nit-picking probably but there names seem to get more and
more mixed up these days.

cheers

Rich

messages.subject: tosho tsuba question
messages.msgSnippet: I bought these 2 tsubas as part of a box lot.  The first is very thin only .098 (2.48 mm) thick by 2.9 (73.66 mm) round.  I know it isn t a good test but it
messages.messageBody:
I bought these 2 tsubas as part of a box lot. The first is very thin only .098" (2.48 mm) thick by 2.9" (73.66 mm) round. I know it isn't a good test but it rings like crystal and sounds unlike other tsubas I have. The plate feels very good in the hand. The patina is darker but the pictures in all were lightened to show texture. Any ideas on the age and what the circle and box represent?



http://www.keepmyfile.com/image/704139293792<http://www.keepmyfile.com/image/704139293792>



http://www.keepmyfile.com/image/b288c9293800<http://www.keepmyfile.com/image/b288c9293800>





The second is a little thicker .125" (3.17mm ) thick by 3.0" (76.71 mm) round. Any idea on the age and what the double circles and thing on the bottom represents?



http://www.keepmyfile.com/image/322a2f293790<http://www.keepmyfile.com/image/322a2f293790>



http://www.keepmyfile.com/image/ad34b9293791<http://www.keepmyfile.com/image/ad34b9293791>





Thanks

Dirk
